fields.description:
Hi there.

Customer is requesting that Stash should be able to use OpenJDK:

{quote}We need to be able to run stash in OpenJDK. I don't understand why Oracle is the only JVM listed in supported platforms.

Currently we run a suite of other Atlassian products (Crowd, Confluence, Jira) as instances of a standard Tomcat server. We would like to add Stash in the same way.

We have no interest in running Oracle's JVM. It requires stepping outside our usual software update process and creates an unnecessary maintenance{quote}

Thank you in advance.

Cheers,
*Douglas Fabretti*
*Atlassian Support*
fields.summary: Run Stash using OpenJDK

{panel:title=Atlassian status as of December 2021|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hi everyone,

Thanks to everyone for voting and commenting on this suggestion. Your input in the comments helps us understand how this affects you and what you're hoping to accomplish with Bitbucket Data Center.

We spend a significant amount of time determining our product investments in Bitbucket Data Center. Unfortunately, we are not planning to address this suggestion in the next 12 months. In the last year, we have resolved many of the highly voted suggestions like Reviewer groups, Pull request templates, capability to enable/disable source branch deletion on merging pull requests and our upcoming roadmap includes a number of other top voted suggestions, including repository archiving. Please check out our [public roadmap|https://www.atlassian.com/roadmap/data-center?product=bitbucket] for more details on the coming soon and future items.

In the meantime, we hope that everyone might consider an established 3rd-party add-on - [Categories for Bitbucket|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/de.communardo.plugin.stash-project-categories/overview]. Our ecosystem is an important aspect of the product, providing flexibility where people want different or additional functionality, and maintaining simplicity where they don't.

I understand that this may be disappointing, but it’s important for us to be open, honest, and transparent with our customers. Product feedback is collected from many different sources and is evaluated when planning the product roadmap. You can [learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].

Cheers,

Imran Khan

Product Manager - Bitbucket Data Center & Server
{panel}

with GIT we need to create more repositories than with subversion, also projects often contain more than one repository. In JIRA you can put projects into categories, it would be nice to be able to do the same thing in Stash, just to keep a better overview and allow people to better relate JIRA and Stash projects.

(we are running version 1.2.4 which does not exist here. the "Affects version" field should be 1.2.4 but Jira does not allow me to do that)

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of November 2021|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#deebff|titleBGColor=#deebff|bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thank you for voting on this suggestion. In Bitbucket Data Center 7.18 we've added HTTP Access Tokens for projects and repositories. More details can be found in the [release notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-data-center-and-server-7-18-release-notes-1087534957.html#BitbucketDataCenterandServer7.18releasenotes-HTTPaccesstokensforprojectsandrepositories] and official [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/http-access-tokens-939515499.html].

For those who are looking for the OAuth 2.0, please vote fo the ticket - BSERV-13061

Anton Genkin
Product Manager
{panel}
h3. Problem Definition

It is inconvenient and in some cases not viable from a security standpoint to use password based authentication to access Bitbucket (eg for REST calls from scripts, CI systems and other tooling).
h3. Suggested Solution

Provide the possibility to authenticate via HTTP using a token based mechanism (possibly OAuth).
fields.summary: Token based HTTP authentication

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of December 2016|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3C78B5|titleBGColor=#3C78B5|bgColor=#E7F4FA}
Hi everyone,

Thanks to everyone for voting and commenting on this suggestion. Your input in the comments helps us understand how this affects you and what you're hoping to accomplish with Bitbucket Server.

This suggestion is currently under consideration by the Bitbucket development team, however we're not able to provide a timeline for when it will be resolved. [Learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].

Regards,

Norman Ma

Product Manager - Bitbucket Server
{panel}

Briefly:
 With Git, users simply "declare" their identity within the configuration of the Git client, which ends up being recorded as the "author" when commits are made against a repository. However, when pushing to a repository hosted within Stash, the identity used to authenticate to the repository may be different then that identity that was recorded when the commits were made.

Furthermore, there is no reliable way to verify or be reasonably certain that commit X was actually performed by user Y. The user could simply have declared their identity to be something false. The lack of a reliable audit trail of changes is a significant issue, particularly for corporations.

One solution to this issue is to require users to perform signed commits (or in the case of pull requests, only allow pull requests against a signed commit tag). The ability is needed to configure a repository to only allow commits that have been signed and verify that the signature is both valid and trusted. At present, this seems to be the only way to establish a reliable audit trail within Git.

Some sources for details:
 [http://git-scm.com/book/en/Git-Basics-Tagging]
 [http://mikegerwitz.com/docs/git-horror-story.html]
 [http://git-blame.blogspot.com/2012/01/using-signed-tag-in-pull-requests.html]
fields.summary: Provide the ability to require and validate signed commits and commit tags

fields.description:
We use a branch naming convention of "feature/XXXXX" for topic branches. When initiating a pull request from one of these feature branches, we always see an error dialog stating "Something went wrong while trying to serve your request. Try reloading the page."

If I ignore and close the dialog, the pull request is created without problems.

This does not occur for other branches without slashes in the name. (The character may be unrelated, but could be a clue)
fields.summary: Create Pull Request shows error for branches with '/' in name

fields.description:
Atlassian Stash shows when a change was committed locally and not when it was pushed to the Stash repository (as I pointed out in support issue SSP-216).

Imagine a developer who works and commits locally, then pushes the changes to Atlassian Stash several days or weeks later. His commit might show up at the bottom of the list of commits in Atlassian Stash, even though he pushed the changes just 5 minutes ago.

This can create confusion for developers and QAs trying to get an idea of what has happened recently, or when looking for who to blame for a recent change.

I therefore request that you add a column to this view: "Push Date". It should look and feel the same as "Commit Date", but it will show when the commit was pushed to Stash. It should be possible to sort on this column.
fields.summary: Show push date in addition to commit date for commits

fields.description:
MySQL isn't listed as a [supported database for versions of Stash prior to 1.2 |https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH010/Connecting+Stash+to+an+external+database]. If you happen to be running on MySQL and you upgrade to 1.2 you hit the following error:

{noformat}
liquibase Change Set liquibase/r1_2/m03.xml::STASHDEV-616-03::dpinn failed.  Error: Error executing SQL ALTER TABLE `stash`.`cs_repo_membership` DROP FOREIGN KEY `fk_cs_repo_membership_changeset`: Error on rename of './stash/cs_repo_membership' to './stash/#sql2-3b6-32e' (errno: 152)
liquibase.exception.DatabaseException: Error executing SQL ALTER TABLE `stash`.`cs_repo_membership` DROP FOREIGN KEY `fk_cs_repo_membership_changeset`: Error on rename of './stash/cs_repo_membership' to './stash/#sql2-3b6-32e' (errno: 152)
{noformat}

The problem is that mysql is treating the identifier arg to {{DROP FOREIGN KEY}} case sensitively, and in the initial schema it was created in ALL CAPS. 

This will be fixed in the next 1.2.x release.
fields.summary: Foreign key recreation fails on mysql when upgrading from 1.1 to 1.2+
Stash supports PostgreSQL 9.1 - consider using more recent version than PostgreSQL JDBC 8.4-701
Awesome start for Git management tool that can be ...

fields.description:
You currently cant authenticate from GitExtensions using putty based ssh authentication. 

This should be a base included feature, as most windows based Git developers are already using this due the simplicity of using pagent to cache credentials of the ssh key. 

The methods of caching the http password mentioned in the help are not satisfactory given one of them involves leaving you password in plain text on your file system.
fields.summary: Support putty based ssh authentication

fields.description:
The {{caches/idx-snapshots}} directory is not safe to delete. Deleting it will cause Stash's indexing process to fall over with exceptions like:

{noformat}
2012-07-30 13:58:37,938 ERROR [pool-4-thread-1] jh 815x27x1 a7bq5z 93.220.70.231,217.115.149.100 /projects/PRJ/repos/my-repo/browse c.a.s.i.i.impl.ChangesetIndexingJob Error during indexing of my-repo
com.atlassian.stash.exception.ServerException: An error occurred while executing an external process: /opt/stash/caches/idx-snapshots/1/1339427723617 (No such file or directory)
...
Caused by: java.io.FileNotFoundException: /opt/stash/caches/idx-snapshots/1/1339427723617 (No such file or directory)
	at java.io.FileInputStream.open(Native Method) ~[na:1.7.0_04]
	at java.io.FileInputStream.<init>(FileInputStream.java:138) ~[na:1.7.0_04]
	at java.io.FileReader.<init>(FileReader.java:72) ~[na:1.7.0_04]
{noformat}

Instead, idx-snapshots should either be moved to {{/data}} to indicate that it is not safe to delete or brought into the DB.

If it is kept on the file system it would be good to make Stash resilient enough to just reindex the entire repository if a file is missing.
fields.summary: Move idx-snapshots out of /caches

fields.description:
Email notifications dont work with Postfix.

Logfile:
postfix/smtpd[26594]: < unknown[192.168.1.52]: EHLO
postfix/smtpd[26594]: > unknown[192.168.1.52]: 501 Syntax: EHLO hostname
postfix/smtpd[26594]: < unknown[192.168.1.52]: HELO
postfix/smtpd[26594]: > unknown[192.168.1.52]: 501 Syntax: HELO hostname

According to the SMTP RFC:
4.2.  Command syntax
The syntax for this command, using the ABNF notation of [2], is:

ehlo-cmd ::= "EHLO" SP domain CR LF

http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc1651
fields.summary: Email send EHLO and HELO commands without hostname
Syntax highlighting for "hpp" extension

fields.description:
According to the documentation:
bq.Once finished, you will not have to do any extra configuration. Your JIRA issues will appear in the changesets and commit lists in Stash. On the JIRA side, the commits associated with a specific issue will appear in the issue's Source tab.

However, Stash will only start indexing and link the commit with the issue if there is a new push to the repository after the Application Link is configured.

If the commit is push to Stash before the Application Link is setup, then there won,t be any link in Stash or commit in JIRA. They will need to push a new commit and Stash will perform indexing to all the commits and link them to JIRA issue again (if the Application Link has already been setup.)
fields.summary: Update on JIRA integration documentation

fields.description:
On Win7:

    Configure STASH_HOME as "c:\Test"
    Create a directory "C:\Test"
    Create another user "B" (that is also an admin)
    Grant "Read", "Read & execute", "Write" to user "B" (admin)
    Launch a new command prompt with "run as user B"
    Run start-stash.bat

*Expected*:
<I am not sure what error message to expect from http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASHKB/Stash+Home+%5B%3CSTASH_HOME%3E%5D+cannot+be+created>

*Actual*:
The database, as currently configured, is not accessible.

Notes:
- Error goes away and Stash starts successfully once "Modify" permission is granted to user "B"
- Note that the error does not mention what was the STASH_HOME directory, nor a link to help.
fields.summary: Startup: Incorrect error if user running Stash does not have Modify permission on STASH_HOME

fields.description:
On Win7:

- Configure STASH_HOME as "c:\Test"
- Create a directory "C:\Test"
- Clear all permissions and grant all to user "A" (admin)
- Create another user "B" (that is also an admin)
- Launch a new command prompt with "run as user B"
- Run start-stash.bat

*Expected*:
Stash Home [<STASH_HOME>] exists but is not readable by Stash

*Actual*
The Spring WebApplicationContext could not be started

Note:
- The same error is reported if user "B" is granted "Read", "List folder contents" and "Read & execute" on STASH_HOME directory.
- Note that the error does not mention what was the STASH_HOME directory, nor a link to help.
fields.summary: Startup: "Spring WebApplicationContext" error if user running Stash has less than Write permissions on STASH_HOME

fields.description:
To be consistent with the other Atlassian tools, it is recommended that Stash separate the prefix used in the subject line when sending Email from the Application Title setting.

We use filters to file our incoming Email and use a prefix like [Jira] and [Confluence] and would like to use [Stash] without changing the Application Title setting for Stash.
fields.summary: Add a Prefix field to Email server configuration.

fields.description:
We have identified and fixed a persistent cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities that affects  Stash instances, including publicly available instances (that is, Internet-facing servers). XSS vulnerabilities allow an attacker to embed their own JavaScript into a Stash page.

More information is available in advisory at https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Stash+security+advisory+2012-09-04
fields.summary: Persistent Cross Site Scripting Vulnerability

fields.description:

A customer came to us looking for a away to change default Project Permissions to all Projects in Stash. He would like to change from "No Access" to "Contributor".

Like the permissions scheme on JIRA, you can modify it and then all Projects have the same default permissions.

Thank you in advance.

Cheers,
*Douglas Fabretti*
*Atlassian Support*
fields.summary: Change default project permissions on all Projects

fields.description:
All of the displayed references to a repository path for cloning always use an http:// prefix, but in our case should all be https://

You have a system setting for the Base URL so why don't you use it?  We have stash running such that only https access is available, and while some clone operations will succeed and internally redirect to https from http, we always have to manually edit the git config to be able to push anything.

The {{atlassian-stash-log}} file shows the following error: 

{code}
com.atlassian.templaterenderer.RenderingException: org.apache.velocity.exception.MethodInvocationException: Invocation of method 'getOrphanedTrustCertificates' in  class com.atlassian.applinks.ui.velocity.ListApplicationLinksContext threw exception java.lang.IllegalStateException: java.security.spec.InvalidKeySpecException: java.io.EOFException at com/atlassian/applinks/ui/admin/list_application_links.vm[line 66, column 20]
{code}

fields.description:
When browsing repository files, certain programming languages have very nice syntax highlighting applied right in the browser.

This is not the case for SQL files. In our environment will be managing both Java projects, and Oracle PL/SQL projects using Stash. Support for SQL syntax highlighting would be a nice touch.
fields.summary: Some SQL scripts are not syntax highlighted

fields.description:
Hello there.

It would be great if Stash had the functionality to find out (e.g. via REST API) how much disk storage is used by a given repository.

Thank you in advance.

Cheers,
*Douglas Fabretti*
*Atlassian Support*
fields.summary: Ability to find git repo statistics (diskspace used, etc)

fields.description:
Hello there guys.

It would be great if Stash had this functionality; a way to set a disk quota on project/repository level.

Thank you in advance.

Cheers,
*Douglas Fabretti*
*Atlassian Support*
fields.summary: Ability to set Quota on Project/Repository level

fields.description:
{panel:title=Update from Support}
We've typically seen this error when users were trying to directly SSH into the Stash server over the SSH service provided by Stash using a Windows client. Stash only supports executing Git operations over SSH and does not allow any other type of SSH access. More information can be found at [dispatch_protocol_error: type 100 seq 8 Error When Connecting via SSH|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASHKB/dispatch_protocol_error%3A+type+100+seq+8+Error+When+Connecting+via+SSH].{panel}

We are attempting to setup our Jenkins CI server to pull projects from our trial Stash server. Jenkins is installed on a Windows 7 64-bit machine running OpenSSH 4.6p1 client from our Git installation (msysGit 1.7). When attempting to clone a git repository on this machine, we get the following:

{{$ git clone ssh://git@dc2build:7999/ADD/projectname.git}}
{{Cloning into 'projectname'...}}
{{usage: ssh \[-1246AaCfgkMNnqsTtVvXxY] \[-b bind_address] \[-c cipher_spec]}}
{{\[-D \[bind_address:]port] \[-e escape_char] \[-F configfile]}}
{{\[-i identity_file] \[-L \[bind_address:]port:host:hostport]}}
{{\[-l login_name] \[-m mac_spec] \[-O ctl_cmd] \[-o option] \[-p port]}}
{{\[-R \[bind_address:]port:host:hostport] \[-S ctl_path]}}
{{\[-w local_tun\[:remote_tun]] \[user@]hostname \[command]}}
{{fatal: The remote end hung up unexpectedly}}

We are however able to clone the repository using the same SSH key via SpringSource Tool Suite on the same machine. 

When attempting to SSH to Stash on port 7999 to verify that our keys are working, the key authenticates and then we get a {{dispatch_protocol_error: type 100 seq 8}}

We've duplicated this behavior on several Windows 7 64-bit machines, using several SSH clients and msysGit 1.7

Our ssh config file is as follows:
{quote}
Host dc2build
  Port 7999
  HostName dc2build
  IdentityFile /d/jenkins/.ssh/id_rsa
{quote}

fields.description:
As a Stash administrator, I need to be able to install and run Stash using the JVM/JDK which ships with my Linux OS, so that I can reduce the administration and maintenance burden caused by needing to keep an additional external software package patched and up to date.

The default JVM/JDK which currently ships with many distributions (and will soon ship with most others) is OpenJDK 7 which is based on the same codebase as Oracle JDK7.
fields.summary: Support OpenJDK7

The REST API doesn't appear to work with fully qualified branch names (e.g refs/heads/master) returning a 400 Bad Request on my local machine and a 404 on stash-dev. The same call with the unqualified branch names (i.e master) works as expected. 

Doesn't work: 
https://stash-dev.atlassian.com/rest/api/latest/projects/STASH/repos/stash/commit/refs%2Fheads%2F1.0/changes?to=refs%2Fheads%2Fmaster&start=0&limit=1000

Works: 
https://stash-dev.atlassian.com/rest/api/latest/projects/STASH/repos/stash/commit/1.0/changes?to=master&start=0&limit=1000
fields.summary: REST API doesn't work with fully qualified branch names

fields.description:
This bug reveals itself when Stash is restarted against a PostgreSQL database for which the default schema is other than 'public'; for example, a schema called 'stash'. We'll call the non-'public' schema the custom schema.

Stash installs itself correctly into the custom schema and operates without error against it; however, when Stash is restarted, a PSQLException is thrown, and an error message appears: "A fatal error has occurred: The Spring WebApplicationContext could not be started."
fields.summary: Error on Stash restart against custom PostgreSQL schema

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of April 2020|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#deebff|titleBGColor=#deebff|bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi all,

I'm excited to share that in Bitbucket Server 7.1 we shipped *Push log* feature that allows admins to see the history of all push events in a repository.

You can find more information in the Bitbucket Server 7.1 [release notes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-7-1-release-notes-998641213.html] and Push log [docs|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/push-logs-998882984.html].

Please, don't hesitate to leave feedback on the feature in the comments. This will help us to priorities further development.
----
Bitbucket also has several features that help sign and verify commits:
 * [Committer Verification hook|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-5-0-release-notes-889528342.html#BitbucketServer5.0releasenotes-Committerverification] which verifies that the committer for each new commit being pushed matches the credentials of the person doing the push.
 * [Verify Commit Signature hook|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-server-5-1-release-notes-902140366.html#BitbucketServer5.1releasenotes-GPGsignedcommits] requires GPG-signed commits in order to push. When it is enabled, each new commit or tag must be GPG-signed with a valid key, and that key must be associated with an active user account on the server. Otherwise the push is rejected.

Anton Genkin
 Product Manager Bitbucket Server
{panel}
*Original request description*

When performing a push, the author that is displayed by Stash is just taken from the author in the local git configuration, so essentially another developer can commit code against another developer's name and push it to the server to make it appear like that developer committed the code change.

In other words, when performing a push, stash doesn't ensure that the user performing the push is the same user as the GIT comitter. This allowed an authenticated user to push updates that appear to come from a different user by configuring their local GIT client with a different username/email address. I can see we may be able to work around this by implementing a GIT hookthat checks the REMOTE_USER variable exposed by Stash.

Are there plans to implement this functionality directly into the product to improve security?

We need to have complete traceability on the push to the shared repository, is there a way of achieving this with Stash
fields.summary: Push Traceability

fields.description:
It looks right now Stash runs on only one machine at a time. 

To be able to have all our repositories (hundreds to thousands) run on Stash it needs to scale out instead of up by running on multiple servers while still being accessible through one url.
fields.summary: Distribute load over multiple servers

fields.description:
Following your example, I have set up haproxy to forward SSH from 7999 to the default SSH port 22. I can successfully clone repos with this setup.

Furthermore, I have set up haproxy to forward HTTP from 7990 to the default HTTP port 80. I can log into the web interface from my Windows machine without having to specify the port, but cloning repos fails with the following error:

$ git clone http://192.168.184.132/scm/myrepo.git
Cloning into 'myrepo'...
Username for 'http://192.168.184.132': <username>
Password for 'http://<username>@192.168.184.132':
remote: Counting objects: 3497, done.
remote: Compressing objects: 100% (1264/1264), done.
remote: Total 3497 (delta 2150), reused 3473 (delta 2138)
Receiving objects: 100% (3497/3497), 1.19 MiB, done.
Resolving deltas: 100% (2150/2150), done.
error: RPC failed; result=18, HTTP code = 200

This works correctly if I bypass haproxy and specifying the port:
$ git clone http://192.168.184.132:7990/scm/myrepo.git
fields.summary: Unable to clone repository using HTTP transport over haproxy

fields.description:
Stash's REST endpoints tend to follow very RESTful structure, but the URLs for the CrowdAdminResource are widely varied on how they work. For example, creating a user or a group requires a POST request, as expected, but the payload is never examined; instead, all of the user or group's properties must be provided as query parameters. Removing a user from a group is also a POST request, rather than a DELETE request, and takes a JSON payload rather than query parameters.

If you are trying to automate user management in Stash using our REST services, you will run into a lot of pain with doing so. Some is documentation-related, but some is caused by the inconsistency of how the API is constructed.
fields.summary: CrowdAdminResource is not very RESTful

Since we can't edit the markup directly in newer Confluence releases, this would be a great way to make such editing available. (I'd rather do my editing locally, anyway.)

Thanks.

fields.description:
Setup:
- Stash with Crowd-authentication
- a Crowd user "jack" that is member of group "stash-users"
- a Crowd user "jill" that is not member of this group
- a Stash project "myproject" that grants "contributor" permission to both user "jill" and group "stash-users"
- a Stash repo "repo" that belonghs to "myproject"

Now, "jack" is able to push to "repo", but "jill" is not (authentication fails)...
fields.summary: Assigning Crowd users to a Stash project doesn't work

Stash event management is great but one issue I have noticed is that the RepositoryPushEvent doesn't give any details about the changeset.

https://developer.atlassian.com/static/javadoc/stash/latest/reference/com/atlassian/stash/event/RepositoryPushEvent.html

Can we include that too?
fields.summary: Retrieve changesets from RepositoryPushEvent

We will provide a fix that works around this issue, but if you have created Trusted application links they may have been set up using a certificate that will no longer be used by Stash, meaning you may get errors when using those application links.

You should disable Trusted Applications on your incoming and outgoing authentication tabs of the configure application link screen to resolve this issue.
fields.summary: Unable to delete Application Link in Stash

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of December 2021|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3c78b5|titleBGColor=#3c78b5|bgColor=#e7f4fa}
Hi everyone,

Thanks to everyone for voting and commenting on this suggestion. Your input in the comments helps us understand how this affects you and what you're hoping to accomplish with Bitbucket Data Center.

We spend a significant amount of time determining our product investments in Bitbucket Data Center. Unfortunately, we are not planning to address this suggestion in the next 12 months. In the last year, we have resolved many of the highly voted suggestions like Reviewer groups, Pull request templates, capability to enable/disable source branch deletion on merging pull requests and our upcoming roadmap includes a number of other top voted suggestions, including repository archiving. Please check out our [public roadmap|https://www.atlassian.com/roadmap/data-center?product=bitbucket] for more details on the coming soon and future items.

In the meantime, we hope that everyone might consider an established 3rd-party add-on - [Snippets for Bitbucket Server|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.simplenia.stash.plugins.snippets/server/overview]. Our ecosystem is an important aspect of the product, providing flexibility where people want different or additional functionality, and maintaining simplicity where they don't.

I understand that this may be disappointing, but it’s important for us to be open, honest, and transparent with our customers. Product feedback is collected from many different sources and is evaluated when planning the product roadmap. You can [learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].

Cheers,

Imran Khan

Product Manager - Bitbucket Data Center & Server
{panel}
*Original request description*

Implement ability to share arbitrary snippets of code with other team members. Snippets should have sharable direct links, be versioned and accept comments/changes.
fields.summary: Code snippet sharing

fields.description:
It looks like JS/CSS resources that are declared in {{atlassian-plugin.xml}} with a [context|https://developer.atlassian.com/display/PLUGINFRAMEWORK/Web+Resource+Plugin+Module#WebResourcePluginModule-WebResourceContexts] of {{atl.admin}} are not being loaded on admin pages. Conversely, the admin pages _are_ loading resources with the context {{atl.general}}, which is supposed to be for everything _except_ admin pages.

This was noticed in [UPM-2254|https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/UPM-2254], but would presumably affect any plugin that wants to decorate any pages that aren't its own.
fields.summary: Admin pages are including web resources with context "atl.general" instead of "atl.admin".

Suggest showing plugin information as a table rather then as a list of expandable elements with no identifying information:
!Atlassian Support Tools - Stash.png!
fields.summary: Support Tools - System Information - Plugins - Display as a table

fields.description:
Stash doesn't seem to do much with submodules.  From what I've seen, if a repository has a submodule, Stash simply displays the .gitmodules file.  I think there are a few things Stash could do.

From a user perspective:

1. An option to show the submodule folder (perhaps in a different style, or annotated as a submodule in some way) and files based on the commit state of the main repository.  
2. An option to list submodules for a project and link to the underlying repository

For example, github shows the sizzle submodule in https://github.com/jquery/jquery/tree/master/src with a link to the repository for the submodule and includes the current changeset.

From an administrative perspective (I suspect some/all of these may not even be possible based on my admittedly limited understanding of Git):

1. Configure repository permissions separately for when a repository is used as a submodule (e.g. read-only when used as a submodule, but full permissions when used as a regular repository).
2. An option to have Stash assume "--recursive" behavior for clone operations
3. An option to keep submodules in sync when a user performs a pull or rebase (the equivalent of forcing a submodule update)
fields.summary: Add Support for Submodules

fields.description:
The {{JiraKeyIndexer}} checks if there is a System property {{stash.jira.key.pattern}} set to overwrite the default pattern with.

In the actual check for a JIRA key in the commit message only the default pattern is used. This is not what I would expected.
fields.summary: JiraKeyIndexer doesn't take systemproperty into account

fields.description:
In cases where the only authentication / user database is crowd (which is read-only), the public sign up check box should be greyed out or automatically unchecked. 

Additionally, a warning should appear when public sign-up is enabled and then later crowd is added and the internal directory is disabled.

Currently, it appears to allow enabling public signup when crowd is the only enabled authentication database. Trying to add a user in this case generates an error (attached screenshot).
fields.summary: Automatically disable public sign up or at least give warning when public sign-up is enabled and crowd is used

fields.description: Rather then having numbers for repo names, please give them a better name.  Also inside of the repo, put some data in the description file.
fields.summary: Make repository names have meaning

fields.description: Would like the ability to add files to repositories via drag and drop in Stash. This would ease the acceptance of migrating to Stash/Git from older legacy SVM systems.
fields.summary: Need the ability to add files to Git repositories inside Stash

fields.description:
I have set up a new Stash test instance. One of the first things I've done is to set up Crowd as the user directory and to disabled the internal directory. 

As Crowd is read-only (and will always be read-only from Stash's point of view), the "Add Users" box on the dashboard has no purpose and would potentially lead to confusion as local group/user management is not possible from Stash. Clicking on the link brings the user to Stash's admin page, but it probably should just be hidden.

Additionally, when viewing a group (see screenshot), the Add Users link exists but the only directory available (crowd) is read-only and so no changes can actually be made.
fields.summary: Hide "Add Users" from Stash dashboard and Group administration if internal directory is disabled

fields.description:
For Reference: https://github.com/blog/966-improved-subversion-client-support

The Reasoning behind this: Our development shop is currently using SVN, the developers want to switch to git, but the management can't justify porting over all our different scripts that depend on SVN. Nor do they want to manage two systems.

Having SVN Client support would allow us to migrate over to STASH while maintaining legacy SVN client support for the scripts that require it.
fields.summary: Add SVN Client Support

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of December 2016|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3C78B5|titleBGColor=#3C78B5|bgColor=#E7F4FA}
Hi everyone,

Thanks to everyone for voting and commenting on this suggestion. Your input in the comments helps us understand how this affects you and what you're hoping to accomplish with Bitbucket Server.

We spend a significant amount of time on an ongoing basis to determine our product investments in Bitbucket Server. Unfortunately, we are not currently planning to address this suggestion in the next 12 months. In the last 12 months, we've resolved 10 of the top 30 feature requests, and our upcoming roadmap includes a number of other top voted suggestions, including in-browser editing, improvements to search functionality, better JIRA integration, and providing an even better code review experience.

In the meantime, we hope that everyone might consider an established 3rd-party add-on - [Activity Streams for Bitbucket Server|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/ch.mibex.stash.rss4stash/overview]. Our ecosystem is an important aspect of the product, providing flexibility where people want different or additional functionality, and maintaining simplicity where they don't.

I understand that this may be disappointing, but we believe it’s important for us to be open, honest and transparent with our customers. Product feedback is collected from a number of different sources and is evaluated when planning the product roadmap. You can [learn more about our process here|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com].

Norman Ma

Product Manager - Bitbucket Server
{panel}

*Original request description*

Add RSS feeds to follow:
* commits of each project
* all commits
* ...
Like in Fisheye.
fields.summary: RSS feeds

fields.description:
git 1.7.10.1 on OSX

When I try to create a repository with e.g. a slash in the name, it is not accepted with the message
"Repository names are limited to 64 characters. They must start with a letter or number and may contain spaces, hyphens, underscores and periods"

However, in Stash 1.1.0 a repo with a period in its name causes problems.

Stash 1.0.3: git clone works fine
{noformat}
$ git clone http://admin@localhost:7990/git/TESTPROJECT_1/testrepo_1.0.git
Cloning into 'testrepo_1.0'...
Password for 'http://admin@localhost:7990': 
warning: You appear to have cloned an empty repository.
{noformat}

Stash 1.1.0: git clone using http fails, using ssh succeeds
{noformat}
$ git clone http://rene@localhost:7990/scm/RENE/test.git
Cloning into 'test'...
Password for 'http://rene@localhost:7990': 
warning: You appear to have cloned an empty repository.

$ git clone http://rene@localhost:7990/scm/RENE/test_2.git
Cloning into 'test_2'...
Password for 'http://rene@localhost:7990': 
warning: You appear to have cloned an empty repository.

$ git clone http://rene@localhost:7990/scm/RENE/test_1.0.git
Cloning into 'test_1.0'...
Password for 'http://rene@localhost:7990': 
fatal: remote error: Repository does not exist
The requested repository does not exist, or you do not have permission to
access it.

$ git clone http://rene@localhost:7990/scm/RENE/te.st.git
Cloning into 'te.st'...
Password for 'http://rene@localhost:7990': 
fatal: remote error: Repository does not exist
The requested repository does not exist, or you do not have permission to
access it.

$ git clone ssh://git@localhost:7999/RENE/test.git
Cloning into 'test'...
Enter passphrase for key '/Users/rverschoor/.ssh/id_rsa': 
warning: You appear to have cloned an empty repository.

$ git clone ssh://git@localhost:7999/RENE/test_1.0.git
Cloning into 'test_1.0'...
Enter passphrase for key '/Users/rverschoor/.ssh/id_rsa': 
warning: You appear to have cloned an empty repository.
{noformat}
fields.summary: Period in repo name causes problems

fields.description:
I had running 1.0.3 with repositories like mydomain.com, which resulted in repository url's like /mydomain.com.git obviously.

Since upgrading to 1.1.0 those do not work anymore. After renaming the repository, all works well again. If I tried to query a repository named like that, I got repository does not exist or no permission.
fields.summary: Cannot clone repositories with '.' in name over HTTP
Git HTTP access is broken in Stash 1.1

fields.description:
We currently have a Gitolite system and have a couple hundred repositories. In the Stash documentation I don't see a way to import repositories from a disk store.

Ideally I'd be able to point Stash at a directory on-disk and say "grab these repositories and create a new project for each" -- or even better, create a new project for all repositories under a common path.
fields.summary: Import repositories on-disk

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of June 2015|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#3C78B5|titleBGColor=#3C78B5|bgColor=#E7F4FA}
 Thanks for all your votes and comments on this suggestion.

This is a good idea and something we would like to see in Stash and FishEye, but at this point we do not currently have any plans to implement this into the products in the near future. We will be sure to update this issue when we have a better idea of when we might start working on it.

In the mean time, if FishEye and Stash are already integrated, you can [easily add individual Stash Repositories to FishEye|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Integrating+FishEye+with+Stash#IntegratingFishEyewithStash-EasilyaddStashrepositoriestoFishEye].

Product feedback is collected from a number of different sources and is evaluated when planning the product roadmap. If you would like to know more about how Atlassian Product Management uses customer input during the planning process, please see [this post on Atlassian Answers|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/110373/how-does-the-jira-team-use-jira-atlassian-com] and our [new features policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/New+features+policy]. 

Thanks for your patience and we hope you appreciate our open approach to feature requests. 
Steve King
Product Manager - Stash  {panel}

h3. Original request description

I don't really want to have to manually create FishEye projects for every repo in Stash. A way to populate FishEye when a repo is created in Stash would be nice...or at least some very easy way to do it (ideally one that doesn't involve an administrator).

h3. Workaround

Use Fisheye's REST APIs to add repositories and set up their permissions:

{{/rest-service-fecru/admin/repositories}}
{{/rest-service-fecru/admin/repositories/<repository>/permissions}}
{{/rest-service-fecru/admin/repositories/<repository>/permissions/groups}}

References:

* https://developer.atlassian.com/server/fisheye-crucible/rest-api-guide/
* https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/fecru-rest-examples/src/master/
* https://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/latest/wadl/fecru.html
* https://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/latest/wadl/fisheye.html
* https://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/latest/wadl/crucible.html
fields.summary: Automatically add repositories to FishEye

fields.description:
Related to STASH-2507. There's a comment on that bug noting that there should be an accompanying permission for push rewind and I felt it deserved a separate request.

At my company we create many short-lived branches, so deleting them is common, but we rarely want people to do a rewind.
fields.summary: Add user permission for allowing/denying non fast forward pushes
Add read/write support for Crowd directories

fields.description: It will be great for our customers if we could implement support to external database migration in Stash.
fields.summary: Stash Database Migration Tool - Allow migration to external database

fields.description:
At work, my username is my userId so it's my git user.name and my JIRA/Stash username, but my displayName is "FirstName LastName".
When creating a repository in Stash, it proposes to set my git user.name to my displayName.
If I use my userId, the commits listing page still use the right avatar from Gravatar but display my userId. Could be better to display my displayName (maybe with a link to the corresponding profile).

So Stash should match my user on my userId and/or displayName and always display the displayName.
fields.summary: Match on username

fields.description:
When viewing a commit, the date is formatted in "DD MMM YYYY" format.
The time ("HH:MI:SS") should be available too.
fields.summary: Display time in commit date

fields.description:
Stash works fine when launching with {{stash-start.bat}}, but when installed as a service, I have a "FATAL: STAH_HOME or stash.home undefined" error.
My solution was to modify {{service.bat}} to add {{-Dstash.home=<MY_STASH_HOME>}} in JvmOptions at line 118.
fields.summary: STASH_HOME not defined when using Stash as a service

fields.description: If Stash is going to be the DVCS manager of Atlassian suite, it would be nice to support also Bazaar.
fields.summary: Add Bazaar support in Stash

fields.description:
I hosted jira and stash toggether and start having the follow error on jira instance when indexing: Caused by: org.ofbiz.core.entity.GenericDataSourceException: Unable to esablish a connection with the database. (FATAL: connection limit exceeded for non-superusers)

I open an terminal and search in postgresql for connections with the query:

select * from pg_stat_activity ;
The search results in 74 connections refining the search with  select * from pg_stat_activity where datname = 'stash' return 64 connection a lot of idle connections is returned, and no one is using the stash instance.

I using stash 1.0.3 with postgresql 8.4 and ubuntu 10.04
fields.summary: Too many database connections
